title: 108_s2160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children's Listbroker Privacy Act." The Congress finds that commercial list brokers sell detailed information on children for marketing purposes, including names, addresses, ages, and other data. These databases can cover millions of children and include information on ethnicity, family income, and hobbies. Marketing to children is a $12 billion per year industry. Several Federal statutes, such as the No Child Left Behind Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, restrict the collection and disclosure of information about children or students. However, when data on children is collected outside of these statutes, Federal law does not significantly limit the commercial sale or resale of such data. This creates an economic incentive to find new ways to collect and sell children's information, potentially circumventing existing regulations. Marketers and list brokers use various means to gather data about children, including names and addresses. Restriction on sale or purchase of children's personal information. Restriction on sale or purchase of children's personal information prohibits selling or buying personal information about a known child without parental consent or violating certification terms. Exceptions include parental consent and certification for certain cases. Certification is required for the sale of personal information about a child, ensuring that the purchaser specifies the purpose of use and agrees not to use it for marketing to the child or allow others to do so. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT. The Act will be enforced by the Commission as if violations were unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Enforcement for certain entities will be under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act by specific agencies. The Act will be enforced by specific agencies for certain entities, including banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and savings associations with insured deposits. The Act will be enforced by specific agencies for entities such as banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Federal credit unions, air carriers, activities subject to the Packers and Stockyards Act, and entities under the Farm Credit Act of 1971. The Act will be enforced by specific agencies for entities such as banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Federal credit unions, air carriers, activities subject to the Packers and Stockyards Act, and entities under the Farm Credit Act of 1971. The agencies mentioned in the Act have the power to enforce compliance with its requirements and may exercise additional authority conferred by law to ensure adherence to the Act. The Commission is tasked with preventing violations of the Act and has the same jurisdiction, powers, and duties as outlined in the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act incorporates provisions from the Federal Trade Commission Act, with penalties and privileges applying to violators. The Commission's authority is preserved, not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ACTIONS BY STATES. The attorney general of a State may bring a civil action in federal court to address practices violating the Act, seeking injunctions, compliance, damages, or other appropriate relief on behalf of residents. Before filing an action under the Act, the attorney general of the State must provide written notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission. An exemption applies if it is not feasible to provide notice before filing the action. The attorney general of a State must notify the Commission and provide a copy of the complaint when filing an action. The Commission has the right to intervene in the action and be heard on any matter that arises, as well as file a petition for appeal. (c) Construction.--For civil actions under subsection (a), State attorney generals can conduct investigations, administer oaths, and compel witnesses. During a Commission action for violation of section 2, no State can initiate a separate action against the same defendant. Venue for actions under subsection (a) can be in any district court of the United States that meets venue requirements under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code. Process serving in such actions can be done in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "child" refers to an individual under 16, "Commission" means the Federal Trade Commission, and "express consent" requires affirmative permission in writing or electronically, with informed consent on the purpose of information use. The term "marketing" refers to promoting commercial products or services for profit. A "parent" includes a legal guardian. "Personal information" includes identifiable details like a name. The term "personal information" includes identifiable details like a name, address, email, phone number, Social Security number, or any other information that identifies an individual. The terms "purchase", "sell", and "sale" in section 3 encompass the buying and selling of the right to use personal information, regardless of limitations, transaction type, or consideration received. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act will take effect 6 months after enactment.
